title: The 35 Best Gifts (That You Can Buy on Amazon) for Every Type of Home Cook
text:
Photo: Courtesy Retailer

When you’re trying to come up with gift ideas for someone who likes to cook, you want to find something that’s both personal and practical. But finding a gift for a home cook that strikes that balance can be hard, especially if you’re the kind of person whose fridge is filled with takeout containers. That’s why we’ve gathered 35 of the best gifts for every type of home cook on your list — from the newbie who just wants to make a good grilled cheese to the home cook who has it all — all of them are available on Amazon, most of them with two-day Prime shipping.

For the home cook who has everything

ChefSteps Joule Sous Vide, 1100 Watts, All White They might not think they need a sous vide machine, but that’s exactly what makes it a great gift for an experienced chef, who can use it to make always-tender steaks, never-overcooked fish, and even soft-scrambled eggs. $179 at Amazon Buy $179 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who would rather use a cookbook

Yamazaki Home Rin Plywood Tablet Stand, Beige A minimalist plywood cookbook-stand for those who still like reading recipes on paper — though it can also hold up a tablet. $25 at Amazon Buy $25 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’d like to throw more dinner parties

MYDrap Cotton Cocktail Napkins We were introduced to these tear-off linen napkins by Tonne Goodman, who discovered them at a boutique in Paris. “Instead of having a stack of napkins that needs to be spread out in an attractive fashion and then wrestled with to gingerly pick just one, you just simply tear each napkin off,” she writes. $19 at Amazon Buy $19 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who wants only one pot

Dansk Kobenstyle Casserole, 4-Quart This colorful Dutch oven from Dansk has a mid-century design that’s easy to cook with but still looks good on the dinner table. It’s made of carbon steel, so it’s lighter than cast-iron Dutch ovens but it’s still sturdy enough to sear, braise, sauté, and bake anything you want. $80 at Amazon Buy $80 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’s not over avocados

For the home cook who got really into celery juice

Breville BJE200XL Compact Juice Fountain 700-Watt Juice Extractor It’s still unclear if celery juice is actually good for you, but if that’s what they’re into, this juice extractor from Breville is powerful enough to make sure none of the stringy bits make it into the liquid (and can be used to make lots of other types of juices, too). $100 at Amazon Buy $100 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook trying to eat more greens

Prepworks by Progressive Collapsible Salad Spinner - 4 Quart $25 (was $33, now 24% off) This collapsible salad spinner is a great gift for the recent college grad who’s got a small kitchen and big culinary ambitions. $25 at Amazon Buy $25 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’s a salt snob

Maldon Salt Pinch Tin Food writer Cristina Mueller always travels with this tin of Maldon sea salt in case of emergencies, explaining, “For years I worked in Alice Waters’s office at Chez Panisse, where desk lunches were breathtaking and the stuff of dreams, and even then I kept Maldon sea salt stashed in my desk. And used it. And never regretted it.” $5 at Amazon Buy $5 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who always brings leftovers to work

LunchBots Large Snack Tray Steel Lunch Container This stainless-steel lunch box is meant for children, but it’s stylish enough to bring to the office and has enough room for a mini-buffet of leftovers. Buy Buy

For the home cook who joined a cookbook club

Creative Co-Op Square Yellow Splatterware Tin Platter This yellow tin splatterware tray is shatterproof, which means there’s no risk of its breaking on the way to the cookbook-club meetup, plus it’s oven safe, so a dish can be warmed up and served on one (very attractive looking) platter. $26 at Amazon Buy $26 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who identified with Antoni on Queer Eye

For the home baker who watches The Great British Baking Show every Friday

For the home cook who’s trying to use fewer paper towels

For the home cook who’s trying to use less plastic

Bee’s Wrap Assorted, 3-Pack These reusable food wraps are made by infusing cotton with beeswax, and they can be used over, and over, and over again — and once they’re finally done for good, they can be composted. $18 at Amazon Buy $18 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’s ready to compost

For the home cook who’s ready for fresh spaghetti

For the home cook who posts all their recipes on Instagram

Nothing Fancy: Unfussy Food for Having People Over $29 (was $33, now 12% off) Alison Roman’s new cookbook is called Nothing Fancy, but that doesn’t mean the recipes won’t be Instagram friendly. $29 at Amazon Buy $29 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who needs fresh herbs

For the home cook who loves their knives

John Boos Chop-N-Slice Maple Wood Reversible Cutting Board $43 (was $58, now 26% off) Cutting boards wear out over time, so any serious home cook will appreciate a brand-new, nice-looking cutting block that’ll protect their sharpened blades. $43 at Amazon Buy $43 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who doesn’t have knives

Takiup Ceramic Knife Set These ceramic knives aren’t perfect, or the fanciest, but according to writer Hannah Howard, they’re excellent for everyday kitchen tasks, and sometimes she prefers using these cheaper blades to her fancy Japanese chef’s knife. Plus, she notes, “I throw the set in the dishwasher with every use, and it has remained in excellent shape.” $24 at Amazon Buy $24 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who keeps accidentally slicing their fingers

OXO Good Grips Adjustable Handheld Mandoline Slicer This mandoline comes with a safety guard to keep vegetables and fruits stable and help prevent slipping fingers from getting sliced. (Chef Gabriel Kreuther also likes a slightly more expensive Japanese mandoline, which comes with its own plastic safety covering.) $15 at Amazon Buy $15 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’s channeling the 1970s

For the home cook who’s still using that slow cooker from the 1970s

Instant Pot DUO60 6 Qt 7-in-1 Multi-Use Programmable Pressure Cooker $70 (was $100, now 30% off) You’ve heard about the Instant Pot even if you don’t cook. It steams, it pressure cooks, it makes yogurt, and it’s got over 36,000 reviews on Amazon, so it’s kind of a no-brainer. $70 at Amazon Buy $70 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who got an Instant Pot last year

OXO Good Grips Pressure Cooker Bakeware Sling Some good Instant Pot accessories will help them make the most of their favorite kitchen gadget, like this silicone sling, which they can use for baking cakes or steaming vegetables in their multifunction pressure cooker. $14 at Amazon Buy $14 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’s already obsessed with a Vitamix

Vitamix Personal Cup Adapter $100 (was $130, now 23% off) This personal cup adapter is a great gift for those who make smoothies in their Vitamix but find the standard 64- or 72-ounce cup a little too big for everyday use, especially since this one fits on basically any legacy model. $100 at Amazon Buy $100 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who struggles to clean their cast-iron skillet

Blisstime Cast Iron Cleaner This little square of chainmail will make removing crud and burnt bits from a cast-iron skillet or Dutch oven a relatively quick and easy task. $9 at Amazon Buy $9 at Amazon Buy

For the at-home pit master who likes to grill on an open flame

For the home baker with limited counter space

KitchenAid Artisan Mini Series Tilt-Head Stand Mixer, 3.5 quart This mini–stand mixer has all the functionality of a standard KitchenAid mixer, but, as writer Erica Murphy notes, “It’s 25 percent lighter and 20 percent smaller,” meaning it’s great for small kitchens. $400 at Amazon Buy $400 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who can taste the difference between Italian and Spanish olive oils

For anyone who likes to read about food as much as they like to eat it

The Best American Food Writing 2019 $12 (was $16, now 25% off) An anthology of the best food essays from the past 12 months, including a deep dive into Japanese KitKats and the queer history of tapas, all edited by Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat’s Samin Nosrat. $12 at Amazon Buy $12 at Amazon Buy

For the ice cream enthusiast who dreams of the perfect scoop

Zeroll Original Ice Cream Easy Scoop This ice cream scoop is “the only ice cream scoop” that Jeni Britton Bauer, the creator of Jeni’s Splendid Ice Cream, will even acknowledge. It’s designed to transfer heat from your hand to the spoon, making it easy to get the perfect scoop from even frozen-solid ice cream. (For bonus points, pair this with a pint or two of ice cream.) $19 at Amazon Buy $19 at Amazon Buy

For the college student looking to hack the perfect dorm-room grilled cheese

For the home cook who puts cracked pepper on everything

Atlas Copper Pepper Mill $50 (was $64, now 22% off) Give a pepper mill that makes a statement. According to writer Juliet Lapidos, this copper one looks like “a tool you’d find at an archaeological dig and — for just that reason — always attracts attention at dinner parties.” $50 at Amazon Buy $50 at Amazon Buy

For the 5-year-old who’s just learning their way in the kitchen

Curious Chef 3-Piece Nylon Knife Set These nylon knives are designed for little foodies who are at least 4 years old, to help them learn basic knife skills while minimizing risk. $9 at Amazon Buy $9 at Amazon Buy

For the home cook who’d rather be making cocktails

Be Your Own Bartender: A Surefire Guide to Finding (and Making) Your Perfect Cocktail $14 (was $25, now 44% off) Gin or whiskey? Easy-drinking or boozy? This cocktail book starts with a comprehensive flowchart to help them figure out exactly what they want to drink and how to make it. $14 at Amazon Buy $14 at Amazon Buy

description: We found the best gifts for home cooks and gift ideas for home cooks that you can buy on Amazon, including ChefSteps Joule Sous-Vide, John Boos Maple Cutting Board, Global 3-Piece Knife Set, and an Instant Pot.
